message.text: @G[c3 stills_103.png]@L @H Message @L Your garrison commander reports that Caesarea is now safe from further pirate raids. Several hideouts have been destroyed, ensuring trade lanes will now be secure. Consider the unexpected ransom demand a thing of the past. @G[more_funds.png] @L@L @H Historical Background @L@L When Caesar invaded North Africa with 6 legions, a storm had scattered his forces leaving him with only 3000 infantry. His former legate named Labienus was commanding some of the Pompeian forces that opposed him. Numidian cavalry, and 120 war elephants under King Juba were used to harass the Romans, and Caesar nearly faced defeat. Eventually, Caesarean forces were victorious at the Battle of Thapsus. In the aftermath, most of the Pompeian leadership took their life or fled Africa; Labienus and many others died on the battlefield. @L@L King Juba would later be killed after losing a duel with the Roman mercenary commander Publius Sittius. @L@L Afterwards, Caesar took the young child successor Juba II captive in order to present him in his triumph in Rome. Captive monarchs in the triumph would be ritualistically strangled in front of the temple to Jupiter Optimus Maximus. While Romans despised human sacrifice, this was the one case where one could compare their practices to it. @L@L During triumph, crowds in Rome would be presented with paintings on wagons for propaganda reasons in the processions. Spoils of war would be shown and some shared with the public. Soldiers would sing disrespectful songs and the triumphator would be dressed in purple and ride a chariot in front of the crowds. @L@L After the civil war ended, Caesar enjoyed four triumphs. One for the Gallic Wars, one for the victory over Pontus in Asian Minor, one for his Egyptian campaign, and one for his North African campaign. @L@L During the North African triumph, Caesar presented the occasion as fighting against the Numidians as celebrating the deaths of Romans during the civil war would not be seen favorably nor would allow for a triumph. @L@L In the paintings, however, it was depicted how Cato took his own life by disemboweling himself and how the Pompeian commander-in-chief Metellus Scipio stabbed himself and was cast into the sea. @L@L This turned the crowds against the triumph and when the child king was shown, they demanded and screamed at Caesar that the child king be released. Caesar obliged and enrolled Juba II into a prestigious Roman school. A similar demand was later pressed regarding Cleopatra's sister Arsinoe IV, who was freed and put to serve in a Roman temple. @L@L@L@L
